Good man!
There are four kinds of dharmas that cause one to lose the wisdom of a bodhisattva.
What are the four?
Having no respectful mind towards the true Dharma of the Buddha, and also not respecting those who expound the Dharma;
Being stingy and jealous of the true Dharma, and not expounding it even if someone comes to seek the true Dharma;
Creating obstacles for those who delight in the Dharma, blocking and concealing it, and giving rise to arrogance oneself;
And further slandering those who expound the true Dharma.
Ratnasaá¹ƒkusumitÄbhijÃ±a!
These four dharmas cause one to lose wisdom.
Good man!
There are four kinds of dharmas that cause the vast wisdom of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas to increase and flourish.
What are the four?
They are: respecting the true Dharma and those who expound the Dharma;

According to what they have heard and attained of the subtle and correct Dharma, they extensively distinguish and explain it for others, not seeking fame or renown, with a mind free from expectations while expounding the Dharma;
diligently seeking the correct Dharma as if saving their head from fire;
according to what they have heard and learned, they firmly uphold it and practice in accordance with the Dharma, not merely reciting its name.
Good man!
Such four dharmas increase the vast wisdom of bodhisattvas.
Good man!
Possessing four dharmas, they all forget the great bodhisattva mahasattva's mind of great bodhi.
What are the four?

Namely, not following the teacher, the preceptor, all fields of blessings, and others, creating doubts where there should be no doubt, slandering those who practice the Mahayana, deceiving oneself and also deceiving others.
Good man!
Such four dharmas lose the mind of bodhi.
Good man!

There are four kinds of dharmas by which bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, lifetime after lifetime, the great mind of enlightenment naturally manifests before them, without being lost in the interim, up to sitting at the site of enlightenment.
What are the four?
Namely, even at the cost of one's life, one never speaks falsely, even in jest;
knowing, one does not speak false words;
one gives rise to an impartial mind towards all beings, the mind without deceit also does not deceive others;
one gives rise to the thought of the World-Honored One towards all bodhisattvas, not delighting in the Lesser Vehicle.
Good man!
Thus, these four dharmas, lifetime after lifetime, the great mind of enlightenment naturally manifests before them, without being lost in the interim, up to sitting at the site of enlightenment.
Good man!
Endowed with four kinds of dharmas, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas cannot give rise to and increase all wholesome roots.
What are the four?
Arrogance, diligently seeking worldly literature and spells, diligently seeking offerings and greedy for fame and reputation, and deceiving others with a deceitful mind.
Good sons!
Endowed with these four dharmas, the wholesome roots of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas will never increase and grow.
Good sons!
Endowed with four dharmas, the wholesome roots of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas increase and grow in every life, becoming more excellent and bright, and they will not regress.
What are the four?
Abandoning all impure dharmas, diligently seeking all pure and correct dharmas. The correct dharmas refer to the six perfections and the bodhisattva canon;
Having no arrogance in one's mind towards sentient beings, like a house dog;
Receiving offerings according to the Dharma and knowing one's own measure, abandoning all kinds of wrong pride and so forth, keeping the mind content and abiding in the holy family;
Not speaking of others' faults, whether true or false, and not seeking others' shortcomings.
If one's mind does not penetrate the dharmas, one will also increase one's wholesome roots in this life and the next, becoming more and more bright and pure, without backsliding.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas have four kinds of deceitful minds that they should always abandon.
What are the four?
Giving rise to doubt, regret, and indecision towards the Buddha Dharma, and thinking like this about those who do not slander:
'Only the Buddha can bear witness.
The Buddha Dharma is immeasurable, taught according to the capacities of sentient beings;
profound and difficult to understand, only the Buddha himself knows it, not something I can comprehend.'
Therefore, do not give rise to a mind of opposition.
Good sons!

This is called the four dharmas that cause sentient beings to give rise to an arrogant mind, a mind of anger and resentment, and a jealous mind towards the gains of others, and to scold and abuse bodhisattvas, spreading their bad reputation.
Good sons!
This is called the four kinds of deceitful minds that bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas should always abandon.
Good sons!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have four kinds of true characteristics.
What are the four?
Namely, regarding offenses committed, they never conceal them, but confess and repent to others, reforming past actions with an unfettered mind;

If speaking the truth would result in the loss of one's country, body, life, or wealth, in such urgent matters one does not abandon truthful speech, nor does one speak differently due to other conditions;

Regarding all evil matters, scolding, slander, beating, binding, and various injuries, when experiencing such suffering, one only blames oneself and attributes it to past karma, not being angry with others or harboring evil thoughts, well abiding in the power of faith due to the purity of one's own mind;
If regarding the profound Dharma of the buddhas, which is difficult to believe and understand, one is able to have faith and acceptance, read, recite, and uphold it.
Good sons!
This is called the bodhisattvas having four true and straightforward characteristics.
Good sons!
They possess four dharmas, the characteristics of being intractable, difficult to tame, and difficult to subdue.
What are the four?
Reciting the scriptures is considered idle talk. Although they speak the Dharma with their mouths, they do not follow it in their actions. They go against admonitions and do not believe them;
They are unable to follow and respectfully make offerings to preceptors, teachers, and fields of merit, causing their minds to be displeased;
They harm the offerings of faith and respect made to others, and themselves violate their original vows while receiving offerings of faith;
They see the well-tamed bodhisattvas and great beings and slight them, being arrogant and not respectful.
Good man!
These are called the four dharmas of bodhisattvas, the characteristics of being intractable, difficult to tame, and difficult to subdue.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas have four characteristics of being well-tamed.
What are the four?
Following the heard Dharma, they skillfully expound it. As they speak, so they practice, relying on the Dharma, not on words;
They can understand the teacher's intentions and are easy to speak with. Whatever they do is good and does not go against the teacher's intentions;
They do not regress in precepts and concentration, and with a disciplined mind they accept offerings;
They see well-disciplined great beings who are faithful and compliant, and with respect and love they follow their good teachings and accept their virtuous practices.
Good man!
These are called the four disciplined appearances of a bodhisattva.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas have four kinds of perversions.
What are the four?

Agreeing with someone untrustworthy is a perversion of the bodhisattva, teaching the profound Dharma to unsuitable beings is a perversion of the bodhisattva, teaching the lesser Dharma to those who delight in the Great Vehicle is a perversion of the bodhisattva, and only giving to those who keep precepts and worship the good while not giving to the wicked is a perversion of the bodhisattva.
Good man!
These are called the four perversions of a bodhisattva.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas have four correct paths.
What are the four?

To all sentient beings, they give rise to an impartial mind, universally believe that sentient beings are equal, and use the wisdom of the Buddha to equally expound the Dharma to all sentient beings, equally causing sentient beings to abide in the correct practice.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva's four correct paths.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas have four non-good friends and companions.
What are the four?
Those who seek the Å›rÄvaka path only wish to benefit themselves;
Those who seek the pratyekabuddha path delight in few affairs in their minds;
They praise external scriptures, the treatises of the LokÄyatas, and the adornments of literature;
Those whom they associate with only increase worldly benefits and do not aspire to the benefits of the Dharma.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva's four non-good friends and companions.
Good man!
Bodhisattvas have four good friends and companions.
What are the four?
Those who come to beg are good friends, because they are causes and conditions for the path;
The one who expounds the Dharma is a good and virtuous friend, because it increases goodness;
Encouraging one to leave the household life is a good and virtuous friend, because it leads one out of the suffering of the three realms;
The buddhas and bodhisattvas are good and virtuous friends, because they increase all correct and wondrous dharmas.
Good man!
These are called the four good and virtuous friends and four good and virtuous companions of the bodhisattva.
Good man!
There are four kinds of people who are not really bodhisattvas but seem to be bodhisattvas.
What are the four?

They are greedy for offerings and not for the Dharma, greedy for fame and not for merit, greedy for their own happiness and not for saving sentient beings, and delight in gathering followers with the Dharma of ending suffering and not in being far away from them.
Good man!
These are called the four who are not really bodhisattvas but seem to be bodhisattvas.
Good man!
There are four kinds of true bodhisattvas.
What are the four?

They are able to believe in emptiness and also believe in the retribution of karma, know that all dharmas are without self, but arouse the great compassionate mind for sentient beings, deeply delight in nirvÄá¹‡a but roam in saá¹ƒsÄra, and whatever giving they do is all for sentient beings, not seeking rewards.
Good sons!
These are the four kinds of true bodhisattva virtues of the bodhisattva.
Good sons!
The bodhisattva has four great treasuries.
What are the four?

If a bodhisattva encounters a Buddha appearing in the world, then he hears the six perfections and their meaning, with an unobstructed mind attends the Dharma teacher, does not temporarily part from him, has no indolence in mind, abides in the araá¹‡ya without negligence.
Good sons!
This is called the bodhisattva having four great treasuries.
Good sons!
The bodhisattva has four kinds of dharmas that can destroy MÄra's affairs.
What are the four?
They never abandon the mind of enlightenment, their minds are unobstructed towards all beings, they are fully aware of all attachments, and their minds do not slight any being.
Good sons!
These are called the four dharmas by which bodhisattvas can destroy demonic affairs.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas have four kinds of inconceivable meritorious virtues.
What are the four?

With a pure mind, they practice the giving of the Dharma, they give rise to a mind of great compassion towards those who violate the precepts, they praise and extol the mind of enlightenment towards all beings, and they cultivate patience towards the powerless.
Good sons!
These are called the four kinds of inconceivable meritorious virtues of bodhisattvas.
Good sons!
Bodhisattvas have four dharmas that shatter afflictions and the ground of ignorance.
What are the four?

The purity of precepts - whether light or heavy - is to not violate any, to uphold the true Dharma without begrudging hard work, to offer lamps and lights and make offerings to the field of merit, to give away wealth without discrimination between close and distant - these are called the four dharmas that shatter afflictions and the ground of ignorance.
Good man!
There are four kinds of dharmas that attain unobstructed cognition.
What are the four?

The mind without expectation always practices the giving of Dharma, upholding the true Dharma in accord with principle, not giving rise to jealousy towards the benefits of others, always subduing one's own mind and not giving rise to arrogance - these are called the four dharmas that attain unobstructed cognition.
Good man!

It is not just by name that one is called a bodhisattva, but by being able to practice good dharmas and act with an impartial mind one is called a bodhisattva. If one is able to accomplish thirty-two dharmas, then one is called a bodhisattva.
What are the thirty-two dharmas?
Always deeply seeking peace and happiness for sentient beings, causing them all to abide in omniscience, always
measuring oneself as a supreme Dharma vessel, not despising the wisdom of others, destroying arrogance,
deeply delighting in the Buddha way, with a firm and sincere mind, ultimately attaining

buddhahood with close friends, always maintaining impartiality towards friends and strangers, always smiling when speaking,ğŸ”½speaking appropriately, greeting first without a frown, never stopping halfway in one's undertakings, universally practicing great compassion equally for all beings,
with an untiring mind, not being averse to hearing much,
reproaching oneself for faults, not criticizing the shortcomings of others, compassionately reprimanding those with offenses,
practicing all deportment with the mind of enlightenment, practicing generosity without seeking repayment, not seeking
birth when practicing discipline, giving rise to unobstructed patience towards all beings, practicing diligence for the sake of cultivating all

For the sake of all wholesome roots, they diligently practice and cultivate. They send away the grasping of the formless realm and take up meditation. They practice skillful means and wisdom, and accord with the four means of gathering disciples. With an impartial mind of loving-kindness towards those who uphold the precepts and those who violate them, they listen with utmost sincerity.

For the sake of all wholesome roots, they diligently practice and cultivate. They abandon the formless realm and take up the meditative absorptions. They practice skillful means and wisdom, and apply the four means of gathering disciples. They have loving kindness and compassion equally for those who uphold the precepts and those who violate them. They listen to the Dharma with a focused mind.

They delight in being far removed from worldly affairs, and dwell in solitary places without attachment to the various worldly glories. They see great benefits in the Mahayana, and avoid evil friends while associating with good friends. They always cultivate the four types of pure thoughts, and play in the five supernormal knowledges. They always rely on
true wisdom, and do not abandon any sentient beings, whether they engage in wrong practices or right practices.
Their speech is always decisive, and they value the true Dharma. All their wholesome roots are headed by the bodhisattva mind.
If a person possesses these thirty-two qualities, then they are called a bodhisattva.
Good man!
The merits of a bodhisattva are immeasurable and boundless. One should know them through analogies and causes.
Good man!ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
It is like the great earth accommodating all beings, with a mind of no discrimination and not seeking repayment of kindness;

Bodhisattvas are also like this. From their initial generation of the mind of enlightenment up to sitting at the site of enlightenment, all beings receive benefits, with a mind of no discrimination and not seeking repayment of kindness.
Good sons!
It is like all water moistening and causing the growth of a hundred kinds of rice, grains, medicinal herbs, groves, and trees;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Because their own minds are pure, they universally cover with compassion and moisten all beings, causing them to increase all wholesome dharmas.
Good sons!
It is like fire that can ripen a hundred kinds of grains, medicinal herbs, flowers, and fruits;
The wisdom of bodhisattvas is also like this, able to accomplish all wholesome roots.
Good sons!
It is like the wind-wheel that can establish all worlds and the buddha-lands;
The skillful means of the bodhisattvas are also like this, all able to establish all wholesome dharmas.
Good sons!
Just as the new moon, with its bright light and color, increases day by day;
The pure mind of the bodhisattvas is also like this, with all wholesome dharmas increasing day by day.
Good sons!
Just as the sun, upon first rising, emits light all at once to illuminate all beings;
The bodhisattvas are also like this, emitting the light of wisdom, all at once illuminating all beings.
Good sons!
Just as the lion king, wherever it goes, is unafraid and unalarmed;
The bodhisattvas are also like this, with pure precepts and true wisdom, wherever they dwell they are unafraid and unalarmed.
Good sons!
It is like a well-trained great dragon elephant king, bearing a heavy load without tiring its body;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Because they skillfully tame their minds, they bear the burden of all sentient beings, bringing great benefit without weariness.
Good man!
It is like a lotus flower born in the water, yet the water does not stain it;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. They are born in the world, yet worldly dharmas do not defile them.
Good man!
It is like when a person cuts down a tree, if the roots are still there it will grow back;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Due to skillful means, although they sever the fetters, they still have the love of wholesome roots and will be reborn in the three realms.
Good man!
It is like the flowing waters of all directions entering the great ocean and becoming of one taste;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. They cultivate wholesome roots through various approaches, dedicating them to supreme perfect enlightenment, all becoming of one taste.
Good man!
It is like Mount Sumeru, the Thirty-three Celestials and the Four Heavenly Kings all rely on it to dwell;
The bodhisattva's great mind of enlightenment is also like this, serving as the basis for the attainment of omniscience.
Good man!
Just as a great king is able to handle state affairs through the power of his ministers;
The wisdom of the bodhisattva is also like this, able to accomplish all buddha-works through the power of skillful means.
Good man!
It is just like when the heavens are clear and free from clouds, there is no sign of rain;
The bodhisattva who lacks learning and understanding, without the rain of the Dharma to nourish, is also like this.
Good man!
It is just like when the heavens are covered with dark clouds, it is able to bring down rain, satisfying beings and causing sprouts to grow;
The bodhisattva is also like this, bringing down the great rain of the Dharma from the clouds of great compassion to benefit beings.
Good man!
Just as wherever the wheel-turning sage king goes, the seven treasures are present;
The bodhisattva is also like this, wherever he appears, the thirty-seven factors of enlightenment manifest in the world.
Good man!
Just as wherever there is a maá¹‡i jewel, there are immeasurable gold, silver, and precious treasures;
In the same way, wherever a bodhisattva appears, there are immeasurable hundreds of thousands of treasures of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas.
Good man!
Just as when the gods of the Thirty-three Heaven enter the mixed treasury garden, whatever they wish for is all there;
Bodhisattvas are also like this. Because of their true and pure mind, they equally teach and transform all sentient beings.
Good man!
It is just like the power of spells and medicine, where poison cannot harm;
The afflictions of bodhisattvas are also like this. Because of the power of wisdom, they do not fall into evil destinies.
Good man!
It is just like the excrement discarded in a great city, which, if placed in sugarcane or grape fields, is beneficial;
The remaining habits and tendencies of bodhisattvas are also like this. They become causes and conditions for omniscience.
Good man!
It is like a person who has never studied the methods of spear and shield, then has no martial use;
Bodhisattvas are also like this, if they have never studied all dharmas, then they are unable to calculate, discern, receive, and uphold the practice.
Good man!
It is like a potter, when the various earthenware vessels are not yet dry, they cannot withstand the great fire;

Bodhisattvas are also like this, towards all beings whose wisdom is weak, they cannot listen to the great Dharma of the Buddhas, therefore they do not expound it for them, if they were to hear it, they would give rise to confusion.
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas who wish to study the subtle sÅ«tra of the Jeweled Cloud should always cultivate the correct contemplation of the true Dharma.
What is correct contemplation?

It is called the correct contemplation of this Dharma to truly contemplate it, not contemplating self, person, sentient beings, or lifespan, this is called the middle way, the true correct contemplation.
Good man!

As for true contemplation, contemplating form as neither permanent nor impermanent, and also contemplating feeling, perception, mental formations, and consciousness as neither permanent nor impermanent, this is called the contemplation of the true reality of the middle way.
Why is it so?

Permanence is one extreme, impermanence is another extreme. Between permanence and impermanence, there is no form, no shape, no life, no cognition. This is called the true contemplation of the reality of all dharmas through the middle way;

Self is one extreme, non-self is another extreme. Between self and non-self, there is no form, no shape, no life, no cognition. This is called the true contemplation of the reality of all dharmas through the middle way.
Good son!

If the mind has reality, that is one extreme; if the mind is not real, that is another extreme. If there is no mind, no mental consciousness, and also no mental factors or fundamental dharmas, this is called the true contemplation of the reality of all dharmas through the middle way.

In the same way, good dharmas and bad dharmas, worldly dharmas and supramundane dharmas, dharmas with faults and dharmas without faults, contaminated and uncontaminated, conditioned and unconditioned, up to defiled and undefiled are also like this. They are apart from the two extremes and cannot be grasped or spoken of. This is called the middle way, the true contemplation of dharmas.
Good sons!

Existence is one extreme, non-existence is another extreme. The middle between existence and non-existence has no form, no shape, no life, and no cognition. This is called the middle way, the true contemplation of the real Dharma.
Good sons!
The twelve links of dependent origination that I have explained:

Ignorance conditions formations, formations condition consciousness, consciousness conditions name-and-form, name-and-form conditions the six sense bases, the six sense bases condition contact, contact conditions feeling, feeling conditions craving, craving conditions grasping, grasping conditions becoming, becoming conditions birth, birth conditions old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress. Thus arises the whole mass of suffering.ğŸ”½If ignorance ceases, formations cease; if formations cease, consciousness ceases; if consciousness ceases, name-and-form ceases; if name-and-form ceases, the six sense bases cease; if the six sense bases cease, contact ceases; if contact ceases, feeling ceases; if feeling ceases, craving ceases; if craving ceases, grasping ceases; if grasping ceases, becoming ceases; if becoming ceases, birth ceases; if birth ceases, thus old age, death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, and distress cease.
The cessation of the whole mass of suffering is thus.
Illumination and ignorance are non-dual and not separate. If one knows thus, this is called the middle way, the true contemplation of all dharmas.

In the same way, action and non-action, consciousness and the cognized, name-and-form, visible and invisible, the six sense bases and non-six sense bases, contact and the contacted, feeling and the cessation of feeling, craving and the cessation of craving, grasping and the cessation of grasping, existence and the cessation of existence, birth and the cessation of birth, old age and death and the cessation of old age and death are all non-dual and without distinction. If one knows this, it is called the middle way, the true contemplation of dharmas.
Furthermore, good man!
The true contemplation does not make dharmas empty because of emptiness, the nature of dharmas is originally empty;
it is not because of signlessness that dharmas are signless, the essence of the nature of dharmas is originally signless;
it is not because of wishlessness that dharmas are wishless, but the nature of dharmas is originally wishless;

it is not because of non-arising, non-birth, non-self, non-grasping, and non-nature that dharmas are non-arising, non-grasping, and non-nature, but dharmas are originally self-non-arising, self-non-grasping, and self-non-nature.
If one contemplates in this way, it is called true contemplation.
Furthermore, good man!
It is not because there is no person that it is called empty, but emptiness is empty by itself;
The past, future, and present are also empty, but the Dharma is empty by itself.
It is not that form ceases to be empty, one should rely on emptiness and not rely on the person.
If one attains emptiness and relies on emptiness, the Buddha says that such a person will fall back.
Good man!
It is better to give rise to the view of self as large as Mount Sumeru than to give rise to the view of emptiness with a sense of superiority.
Why is it so?
All views are liberated through emptiness, if one gives rise to the view of emptiness, it cannot be cured.
Good man!
It is like a doctor prescribing medicine to cure a disease, but the medicine remains inside and does not come out.
What do you think?
Will the patient be cured or not?
No, World-Honored One!
Because the medicine does not come out, the disease will worsen.
Good man!
Such views can only be extinguished by emptiness. If one gives rise to the view of emptiness, then it is incurable.
It is like a person who is afraid of empty space, wailing and beating his chest, saying:
'Remove this empty space!
What do you think?
Can empty space be removed?'
No, World-Honored One!
Good man!
I say that such a person who is afraid of the Dharma of emptiness is insane and has lost their mind.
Why is it so?
Constantly practicing in emptiness, yet fearing emptiness.
It is like a painter who paints a demon's image with their own hands and, upon seeing it, becomes frightened, confused, and falls to the ground;

All ordinary beings are also like this. Because they create forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tactile objects, they go back and forth in birth and death, experiencing various sufferings without realizing it.
Good man!
It is like a magician conjuring a fierce tiger, and the conjured tiger, once formed, still devours the magician;
The Å›ramaá¹‡a who practices the Way is also like this. Whatever dharmas are observed are all empty and still, with nothing to be seen. This observation is also empty.
Good man!
It is like two pieces of wood that originally have no sign of fire. By rubbing them together, fire arises from their contact and then burns the wood.
Good man!
In this way, because of true observation, the holy wisdom arises;
Once the holy wisdom arises, it then extinguishes the true observation.
Good man!

It is like lighting a lamp. All darkness naturally has no existence, does not come from anywhere, and goes nowhere. It does not come from the east and does not go to the south, west, north, the four intermediate directions, above, or below. It does not come from those places and does not go to them.
Yet this lamplight also has no thought:
'I can extinguish the darkness.'
It is only because of the light that the darkness disappears by itself.
Light and darkness are both empty, without action and without grasping.
Good man!
In this way, when true wisdom arises, ignorance disappears by itself. Wisdom and ignorance, these two characteristics, are both empty, without action and without grasping.
Good man!
It is like a dark room that has not seen light for a thousand years. Suppose someone lights a lamp in it.
What do you think?
Would the darkness think:
'I have long dwelt here and do not wish to leave'?
No, World-Honored One!
If the lamp is lit, the darkness will have no power and will surely disappear.
Good man!
In this way, karmic hindrances accumulated over a hundred thousand myriad eons can all be eliminated by a single contemplation.
The light is the holy wisdom roots;
The darkness is the karmic hindrances.
Good man!
It is like planting in empty space, where there is no possibility of growth.
Bodhisattvas taking realization is also like this, where there is no possibility of growth in the Buddha Dharma.
Good sons!
It is like planting in good fields, where there is a possibility of growth.
Bodhisattvas are also like this, with various afflictions and worldly defilements able to grow the Buddha Dharma.
Good sons!
It is like not growing lotus flowers on high plains and dry land;
Bodhisattvas are also like this, not giving rise to the Buddha Dharma in the unconditioned.
Good sons!
It is like growing lotus flowers in low-lying, muddy swamps;
Bodhisattvas are also like this, able to give rise to the Buddha Dharma in the muddy swamps of birth and death and the wrong views of sentient beings.
Good sons!
It is like the four great oceans giving birth to ghee filling them;
The many immeasurable wholesome roots of bodhisattvas are also like this.
Good sons!
It is like if one were to break a single hair into a hundred parts, and with one part of the hair take a drop of water from the ocean;
all the conditioned wholesome roots of the Å›rÄvakas are also like this.
Good sons!
It is like the amount of space in a mustard seed eaten by an insect;
all the conditioned wisdom of the Å›rÄvakas is also like this.
Good sons!
It is like the immeasurable and boundless space in the ten directions;
the conditioned wisdom of the bodhisattvas is also like this.
Good sons!

It is like when a great consort of a wheel-turning sage king becomes pregnant for seven days, and this child possesses the marks of a wheel-turning king, and the gods respect him more than other sons who possess physical strength.
Why is this?
Because this womb-born prince will surely inherit the honored position and continue the lineage of the sage king.
Good sons!
Beginning bodhisattvas are also like this. Although they do not yet fully possess the characteristics of bodhisattvas, like a prince in the womb, the devas and spirit kings deeply respect them.
Why is it so?
Because such bodhisattvas will surely inherit the honored position and not cut off the Buddha's lineage.
Good sons!
It is like a single lapis lazuli gem surpassing crystal;
bodhisattvas are also like this, from the initial arousal of the mind they surpass all types of beings.
Good sons!
It is like when a king's wife gives birth to a child, the vassal kings and ministers all come to pay homage;
bodhisattvas are also like this, when they first arouse the mind, the devas and humans of the world should pay homage.
Good sons!
It is like the king of snow mountains, whose medicinal herbs are everywhere, belonging to no one, making no distinctions, and able to cure whatever illness there may be;
bodhisattvas are also like this, the medicinal knowledge they gather makes no distinctions, universally protecting and rescuing sentient beings equally.
Good sons!
Just as the new moon is loved and respected by the people more than the full moon,
good sons!
In the same way, sentient beings who have faith in my words love and respect the bodhisattvas more than the TathÄgata.
Why is this?
Because the TathÄgata is born from the bodhisattvas.
At that time, the World-Honored One again told the Bodhisattva-MahÄsattva RatnÄkara:
Good sons!

The bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always cultivate pure conduct and supreme wholesome roots for the benefit of all sentient beings. With an impartial mind, they bestow these upon sentient beings. The wisdom medicine they attain reaches everywhere in the ten directions to cure all the afflictions and suffering of sentient beings, causing them to be forever eliminated and never arise again.
What is called the bodhisattvas' wisdom medicine?

That is to say, the contemplation of impurity treats greed and desire, cultivating a compassionate mind treats anger and hatred, the contemplation of causes and conditions treats ignorance and delusion, cultivating the contemplation of emptiness treats all false views, the contemplation of signlessness treats all conceptual thoughts and distinctions of objects, the contemplation of wishlessness treats all wishes to be born in the three realms, the four non-inverted contemplations treat the four inverted views, the contemplation of impermanence treats the inverted view of permanence in the midst of impermanence, cultivating the contemplation of suffering treats the inverted view of happiness in the midst of suffering, the non-self of dharmas treats the inverted view of self in the midst of non-self, and nirvana and quiescence treat the inverted view of purity in the midst of impurity.

The four mindfulnesses of body, feelings, mind, and dharmas are the antidotes to the four kinds of inversions. Contemplating in accordance with the characteristics of the body does not fall into the view of self, contemplating in accordance with the characteristics of feelings does not fall into the view of self, contemplating in accordance with the characteristics of the mind does not fall into the view of self, and contemplating in accordance with the characteristics of dharmas does not fall into the view of self. These four mindfulnesses can treat all bodies, feelings, minds, and dharmas, and open the gate to nirvana.

By means of the four right efforts, one can eliminate the unwholesome dharmas that have already arisen, prevent the unwholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen from arising, cause the wholesome dharmas that have not yet arisen to all arise, and cause the wholesome dharmas that have already arisen to increase and flourish.
In brief, one can eliminate all unwholesome dharmas and accomplish all wholesome dharmas.
The four bases of supernatural power treat the characteristics of the unification of body and mind, enabling one to attain the supernatural powers of mental freedom.

Using these five faculties, he treats all sentient beings who lack faith, are lazy, forgetful, have distracted minds, or lack wisdom. Using these five powers, he subdues all afflictions. Using the seven factors of enlightenment, he treats doubts, regrets, and delusions regarding all dharmas. Using the eightfold noble path, he treats all wrong paths and non-Buddhist teachings.
Good man!
This is the ultimate wisdom and wondrous medicine. Bodhisattvas should always cultivate and diligently practice it.
Good man!
In JambudvÄ«pa, JÄ«vaka is the foremost physician.

If one were to make all sentient beings in the trichiliocosm like JÄ«vaka, and if someone asked them about the medicine for the illnesses of mental afflictions, wrong views, and doubts, they would still be unable to answer, let alone treat them.
In this regard, bodhisattvas should think like this:
'I will never be satisfied with worldly medicine. I will cultivate the supramundane wisdom medicine and also cultivate all wholesome roots and merits.'
In this way, the bodhisattva, having attained the medicine of wisdom, goes everywhere in the ten directions to ultimately cure the afflictions and other illnesses of all sentient beings.
What is the medicine of wisdom that appears in the world of the bodhisattva?

It is to believe and understand that all dharmas arise from the convergence of conditions, to believe that all dharmas are devoid of self, person, sentient being, life, knowledge, and vision, and also devoid of agent and experiencer, and to believe and understand the realization of selflessness and the absence of mine.

Within these empty dharmas, which are devoid of attainment, one should not be frightened or afraid, but should diligently apply effort and seek the characteristics of the mind. The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should seek the mind in this way.
What is the mind?ğŸ”½Is it greed?
Is it anger?
Is it delusion?
Is it past, future, or present?
If the mind is past, the past has already ceased;
if the mind is future, the future has not yet arrived;
if the mind is present, the present has no abiding.
This mind is neither internal, nor external, nor in between; this mind is without form, without cognition, without shape, without seeing, without knowing, without a dwelling place.
Such a mind has never been seen by all the Buddhas of the ten directions and three times, is not being seen now, and will not be seen in the future.
If it is not seen by all the Buddhas of the past, present, and future, how can it exist?
But due to inverted and deluded thoughts, the mind gives rise to various distinctions in phenomena.
Good man!
This mind is like an illusion, with thoughts and distinctions giving rise to various karmas and receiving various bodies.
Good man!
The mind goes like the wind, traveling far to inappropriate objects and being difficult to restrain;
The mind is like a flowing stream, arising and ceasing without abiding;
The mind is like a flame, existing due to various conditions;
This mind is like lightning, not staying for a moment;
The mind is like space, obscured by the defilements of guests and afflictions;
The mind is like a monkey, taking up one thing and abandoning another, wandering through all objects;
The mind is like a painter, able to create various karmic causes and conditions;
The mind has no temporary stability, following various afflictions;
The mind is unique, having no second;
The mind is like a great king, the supreme lord of all dharmas;
The mind always goes alone, having no companion;
The mind is like an enemy, able to create all suffering;
The mind is like a mad elephant trampling a child's earthen house, able to destroy all wholesome roots;
This mind is greedy like a fish swallowing a hook, because it gives rise to the thought of pleasure in the midst of painful feelings;
This mind is like a dream, because it gives rise to the thought of self in the midst of non-self;
The mind is like a blue fly, because it gives rise to the thought of purity in the midst of impurity;
The mind is like a creditor, because it gives rise to bitterness;
The mind is like an evil ghost, because it seeks an opportunity to harm people;
The mind is always high and low because of the oppression of greed and hatred;
The mind is always thieving and robbing because of stealing wholesome roots;
The mind is always greedy for form, like a moth to a flame;
The mind is always greedy for sound, like the sound of a war drum;ğŸ”½The mind is always greedy for smell, like a pig enjoying filth;
The mind is always greedy for taste, like a camel loving honey;
The mind is always greedy for touch, like a fly stuck to oil.
Good man!
The bodhisattva thus seeks the characteristics of the mind but cannot attain them. If they cannot be attained, then they are not past, present, or future;
If they are not past, present, or future, then they transcend the three periods of time;
If they transcend the three periods of time, then they are neither existent nor nonexistent;
If they are neither existent nor nonexistent, then they are unarisen;
That which is unarisen is then without nature;ğŸ”½If without nature, then it is unborn;
If unborn, then it is unceasing;
If unceasing, then there is nothing to be apart from;
If there is no separation, there is no coming, no going, no falling back, and no birth;
If there is no coming or going, no falling back, and no birth, then there are no conditioned activities;
If there are no conditioned activities, then it is unconditioned;
If it is unconditioned, it is the fundamental basis of all sages. In this, there is no upholding of precepts or breaking of precepts;
If there is no upholding of precepts or breaking of precepts, then there is no practice and no non-practice;
If there is no practice or non-practice, then there are no mental or mental factors;
If there are no mental or mental factors, then there is no karma and no karmic retribution;
If there is no karma or karmic retribution, then there is no suffering or joy;

If there is no suffering or joy, that is the nature of the sages. In this, there is no karma, no one who creates karma, no bodily karma, and no mental karma. In this, there is no distinction between high and low.
The nature of the sages is equal, just like empty space;
This nature is equal, without superiority or inferiority, because all dharmas are of one taste;
This nature is equal, far removed from all physical and mental characteristics;
This nature is far removed from all dharmas, because it accords with nirvana;
This nature is pure, because it is far removed from all afflictive defilements;
This nature is selfless, because it is free from the notion of mine;
This nature is true, because it accords with suchness;
This nature is tranquil, because it is always blissful;
This nature is without high or low, because it arises from equality;
This nature is true, because it is the ultimate truth;
This nature is inexhaustible, because it is ultimately unborn;
This nature is eternal, because all dharmas are always thus;
This nature is blissful, because nirvana is supreme;
This nature is pure, because it is free from all characteristics;
This nature is selfless, because it cannot be found through seeking.
Good man!
You should all observe well within yourselves and not run around externally.
Good sons!
The monks of the future will be like dogs chasing after clods.
What is meant by being like dogs chasing after clods?
It is like a person throwing a clod at a dog, and the dog then abandons the person and runs after the clod.
In this way, good sons!

There are monks, faithful men and women who, out of fear of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, dwell in secluded and quiet places, alone without companions, away from the hustle and bustle of the crowd, their bodies free from the five desires but their minds not letting go.
These people think of form, sound, smell, taste, and touch, and their minds greedily cling to them without observing within themselves, not knowing how to be free from the five sense objects.
Because they do not know, sometimes they enter cities, towns, and villages, and while among the people they are again bound by the five desires.
If one has contaminated precepts in a secluded place, one will be reborn in the heavens after death, but will be bound by the five desires of the heavens.

Falling from the heavens, one will never be able to escape the three evil pathsâ€”namely, the hells, animal realm, and hungry ghost realmâ€”this is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a who is like a dog chasing a clod.

It is like a horse trainer who immediately subdues a wild horse;
The practitioner is also like this. Following the direction of the mind, one is able to gather and restrain, not allowing laxity.

It is like a person whose throat is blocked, which can then take away their life;
in the same way, good man!
All views, only the view of self can then take away the life root of wisdom.
Good man!
It is like a person who seeks liberation from wherever they are bound;
in the same way, good man!
One should seek liberation from wherever the mind is attached.
Good man!
Those who have left the household life have two kinds of impure defilements of the mind.

First, reading and reciting worldly literature and non-Buddhist arts; second, hoarding many fine robes, bowls, and various garments.
Moreover, those who have left the household life have two kinds of firm bonds.

First, the bond of attachment; second, the bond of offerings.
Moreover, there are two kinds of obstacles for renunciant practitioners.
What are the two?
First, being close to laypeople; second, hating good friends.
Moreover, there are two kinds of defilements for renunciant practitioners.
What are the two?
First, enduring afflictions; second, seeking benefactors.
Moreover, there are two kinds of hailstorms for renunciant practitioners.
What are the two?
First, destroying good roots and going against the true Dharma;
second, receiving the offerings of others with a body that violates the precepts.
Moreover, there are two kinds of boils and sores for renunciant practitioners.
What are the two?
First, seeking to expose the faults of others; second, covering up one's own offenses.
Moreover, there are two kinds of burning heat for renunciant practitioners.
What are the two?
First, with a defiled mind, cherishing and clinging to Dharma robes; second, receiving offerings from those who uphold the precepts.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Moreover, there are two kinds of illnesses for those who have left the household life.

There is a renunciant who is complete in appearance - wearing a saá¹ƒghÄá¹­Ä«, shaving the beard and hair, and holding a begging bowl - but does not cultivate pure bodily actions, pure verbal actions, and pure mental actions, does not skillfully protect the body, is stingy and jealous, lazy, and violates the precepts while harboring evil. There is a Å›ramaá¹‡a who is fully endowed with the four deportments of a Å›ramaá¹‡a, walking, standing, sitting, and lying down with a focused mind, peacefully and calmly, cutting off all delicious flavors, cultivating the four noble lineages, staying far away from the hustle and bustle of crowds, and speaking softly.

He makes an effort to read and recite, wanting others to know that he is very learned;

He cultivates the Dharma of few desires and contentment, wanting others to know that he is disgusted with worldly affairs.
Not for tranquility, not for attaining the Way, not for the fruits of Å›ramaá¹‡as, not for the sublime and supreme fruits of nirvÄá¹‡a, this is called a Å›ramaá¹‡a who seeks fame.

What is a Å›ramaá¹‡a of true practice?
A Å›ramaá¹‡a who does not even give rise to greed towards his own body and life, let alone to material gain, fame, and reputation,
who greatly rejoices upon hearing of the dharmas of emptiness, signlessness, and non-grasping, who accords with true suchness and practices in accordance with the teachings,
who does not cultivate pure conduct for the sake of nirvÄá¹‡a, let alone delight in the three realms which are devoid of joy,
who does not even grasp at emptiness, let alone the views of self, sentient being, or person,

who seeks liberation by relying on the Dharma - one who seeks liberation does not run outside - who sees all dharmas as originally unstained and ultimately pure, who relies only on oneself and not on others,
who does not even grasp at the Dharma body of the Buddha, let alone the form body,
Since emptiness and detachment do not see dharmas, how much less do they become attached to sounds and words?

Within all dharmas, there is nothing to eliminate, nothing to cultivate, no birth in saá¹ƒsÄra, no attachment to nirvÄá¹‡a. Knowing that all dharmas are originally quiescent, one does not see attainment and does not seek liberation. This is called true practice of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.

You should learn the true practice of the Å›ramaá¹‡a, do not become attached to mere names, which are empty and without benefit.

The person with much learning who has the illness of afflictions is also like this. Although they have much learning, they do not stop afflictions, so how can they benefit themselves?

It is like a person who takes the king's precious medicine but cannot control themselves and is harmed by the medicine;

What are the four?

Suppose there is a person who fully observes the precepts, is always fearful of grave and minor offenses, is able to practice all the precepts they hear, has pure bodily, verbal, and mental actions, and has a correct and pure livelihood. Moreover, there is a person who recites and upholds the precepts, practices according to the teachings, but does not eliminate the view of the self. This is the second precept-breaker who appears to be well-versed in the Vinaya.

Moreover, there is a person who fully observes the precepts, grasps the characteristics of sentient beings, and practices loving-kindness, but is greatly frightened upon hearing that all phenomena are originally unborn. This is the third precept-breaker who appears to be well-versed in the Vinaya.

Moreover, there is a person who fully practices the twelve dhÅ«tas, but sees the characteristics of offenses. This is the fourth precept-breaker who appears to be well-versed in the Vinaya.

Those who uphold the precepts have no self, no possession of self, no action, no non-action, no dharma of action, no agent, no practice, no non-practice, no form, no name, no characteristics, no non-characteristics, no accomplishment, no non-accomplishment, no grasping, no abandoning, nothing to grasp, nothing to discard, no sentient beings, no name of sentient beings, no mind, no name of mind, no mundane world, no non-mundane world, no reliance, no non-reliance. They do not become arrogant due to upholding the precepts, nor do they despise those who violate the precepts. They also do not recollect or discriminate these precepts.
RatnÄkara!
This is called the holy precepts, the precepts without outflows, the precepts without attachment to the three existences, and the precepts without reliance.
At that time, the World-Honored One, wishing to restate this meaning, spoke a verse, saying:

Attaining the illumination of wisdom, without darkness or existence,
Without the notion of self or other, already knowing and seeing all characteristics,

There is no this shore or the other shore, nor is there any middle,
In the absence of this and that, one is not attached to anything,
Unbound, free from defilements, and without deception,

The mind is not attached to names and forms, nor does it give rise to I and mine,
This is called abiding in the true and pure observance of precepts.
Although one observes all precepts, one's mind does not become arrogant,
Nor does one consider it superior, but seeks wisdom beyond the precepts,

Having transcended these two, one cultivates wisdom,
Empty and tranquil, without anything, this is the nature of the sages and saints,
Such pure precepts are praised by the Buddhas.

And has faith and understanding in the empty and tranquil Dharma practiced by the buddhas.
Thus, upholding the holy precepts, one becomes unequaled.ğŸ”½Relying on the precepts, one attains samÄdhi, and through samÄdhi, one can cultivate wisdom.
Relying on the cultivated wisdom, one attains pure cognition.
One who has attained pure cognition is fully endowed with pure precepts.
When the Buddha spoke this teaching, five hundred monks did not grasp at any dharmas and their minds attained liberation;
thirty-two thousand people became free from defilements and attained the purity of the Dharma eye;

five hundred monks attained meditative concentration, but when they heard this profound teaching, their minds did not believe or understand it, they were unable to penetrate it or internalize it, so they rose from their seats and returned to the mountains and forests.
At that time, MahÄkÄÅ›yapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
These five hundred Å›ramaá¹‡as all attained dhyÄna concentration, but because they could not believe, understand, and enter the profound Dharma, they rose from their seats and left.
The Buddha said to MahÄkÄÅ›yapa:
These Å›ramaá¹‡as, due to their arrogance, heard the characteristics of this pure, undefiled precept, but were unable to believe, understand, and fully comprehend it.
The meaning of the verses spoken by the Buddha is extremely profound, and they did not internalize it.

If one lacks merit, has not planted good roots, and follows evil friends, one will be mostly unable to believe and accept this profound Dharma.
KÄÅ›yapa!

These five hundred people were disciples of non-Buddhists during the time of KÄÅ›yapa Buddha in the past. They went to the Buddha's place wishing to find fault with the Buddha. Hearing the Buddha speak the Dharma, they gained a little faith and thought to themselves:

Due to the causes and conditions of this good mind and merit, after their lives ended they were reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
They will fall from there and be reborn in JambudvÄ«pa, where they will leave home to join my monastic order.

However, due to the power of the causes and conditions of hearing the profound teachings, they will attain great benefits. They will not fall into evil destinies in their next lives, but will attain nirvÄá¹‡a in this very body.
At that time, the World-Honored One told the elder SubhÅ«ti:

The elder SubhÅ«ti replied:

Elder!
